Award.AwardTitle: ANTIBACTERIAL MINERAL MAPPING: A NEW ECONOMIC GEOLOGY
Award.AbstractNarration:
With strong evidence from exploratory research supporting that certain natural clay minerals are effective antimicrobial agents, this research will examine the geological environment controlling formation and stability of antibacterial mineral deposits and further explore the antibacterial mechanism. The primary goal is to delineate the scientific basis by which natural clay minerals are able to kill bacteria and promote healing, therefore validating the use of natural clays as an economical treatment for bacterial infections.

A detailed field map of antibacterial minerals in one deposit will be constructed to identify antibacterial zones. The mineralogy of this deposit will be compared to other antibacterial clay samples worldwide, with statistical analysis used to identify the principal components in common. Antibacterial testing of the identified mineralogical/geochemical components will be performed on Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria representative of common infectious diseases.

The results could have broad-reaching applications in topical antimicrobial dressings; wound care management, personal care, and animal care markets. Using a variety of geochemical, mineralogical and microbiological approaches to assess the mineral-microbe interactions, our results will provide insights to the chemical conditions controlling the mineral induced bactericide. Finally, we will use ultra-high resolution (50nm) ion imaging (NanoSIMS) to show where biomolecules within a single cell are being altered by bactericidal reactions. These results may lead to new designs for controlling antibiotic-resistant infections and diseases for which there are no known therapeutic agents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ANTIBACTERIAL MINERAL MAPPING: A NEW ECONOMIC GEOLOGY

Lynda B. Williams, Arizona State University

 

The use of natural clays in wound healing is a practice used by many cultures since prehistoric times. The last decade has seen a renewed interest in the use of natural resources that exhibit antibacterial effects, and in understanding the natural antibacterial processes as an alternative to antibiotics to which bacteria have become tolerant. The goal of this research was to study clay deposits that were shown to be effective at killing certain human pathogens, and in particular antibiotic resistant pathogens. First we determined what made natural clays antibacterial, and second we mapped the antibacterial mineral assemblages in a hydrothermal clay deposit in order to understand the mineralogical controls on the antibacterial effectiveness.

Ferruginous illite-smectite (I-S) is the most common antibacterial clay mineral, although kaolins dominate some samples. Bactericidal clays may contain soluble Fe-phases (e.g., pyrite) or other reduced metals that drive production of reactive oxygen species, damaging cell membranes and intracellular proteins.  Ion exchange with metals leads to loss of membrane bound Ca2+ and Mg2+ and promotes bacterial oxidation. Critically important is the role of the clay mineral assemblage in buffering the water pH to conditions <4 or >10, where Al is soluble. Nanometric particle sizes (<200nm) are a characteristic feature of antibacterial clays suggesting that a high surface area aids solubility on the time scale of topical applications (~24 hrs). Clays can absorb reduced transition metals in their interlayer, and act as a barrier to oxidation. However, when the clays are hydrated with deionized water, cation exchange provides extended release of the antibacterial active components.

Mapping of an antibacterial clay deposit in the Oregon Cascades showed that the most effective clay assemblages contained reduced Fe in the form of sub-micron pyrite, but that the presence of illite-smectite was important for buffering the pH of the hydrated clay poultice to acidic conditions where Fe2+ is soluble. The oxidation state of the mineral poultice was found most effective when the Eh of the suspension was 400 – 750mV, which corresponds to the pH-Eh stability field for aqueous Fe2+. Clays that contain carbonates are outside of the pH stability field for Fe2+ and are not antibacterial. Similarly, where goethite is stable in the clay assemblage, Eh conditions are too high (>800 mV) for Fe2+ stability and the clays are not antibacterial. Using these geochemical guidelines we suggest that many mine tailings from epithermal ore deposits worldwide are likely to contain antibacterial clays. Provided these minerals do not also harbor bioavailable toxic elements, such deposits may have a new economic value as antibacterial agents.

The broader impacts of this work include discovery of a novel antibacterial process that may be implemented in development of new topical treatments to control antibiotic resistant infections. The identification of several antibacterial clay mineral assemblages allows us to identify new natural resources that can be used to control the proliferation of antibiotic resistance.
